summary: This document is a chain of emails from October 2021 between law enforcement personnel (NYPD, FBI, AUSA) and a contractor regarding background checks on potential witnesses for a grand jury (GM) proceeding. The emails discuss obtaining rap sheets, Accurint/Ejustice queries, and converting documents to PDF for 3500 material review.

connections.description: Both are involved in the same task of preparing witness materials for a grand jury proceeding, with M requesting assistance and El handling document conversion.

events.title: Initial Witness List Request
events.description: An Assistant United States Attorney sends a list of potential testifying witnesses to law enforcement, requesting rap sheets be run by Wednesday or Thursday.

events.title: Witness Information Follow-up
events.description: Law enforcement requests more information on witnesses, including DOBs, reasons for testifying, and locations, to assist with background checks.

events.title: Background Check Results Provided
events.description: Accurint/Ejustice queries and NCIC records for a list of individuals are compiled and attached in a Word document for review.

events.title: Document Preparation for 3500 Material
events.description: Email chain discusses converting witness background documents to PDF for review under 3500 purposes (likely referring to Jencks Act material for discovery).

locations: United States Attorney's Office Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The emails are part of preparation for a grand jury (GM) proceeding involving potential witnesses, with law enforcement running background checks (rap sheets, Accurint/Ejustice, NCIC).
An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York is involved, requesting rap sheets on witnesses by a specific deadline.
The correspondence involves the NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force, indicating the case relates to child exploitation and human trafficking.
Document preparation includes converting files to PDF for 3500 material review, which typically refers to Jencks Act disclosures in federal criminal cases.
Multiple witness names are referenced but are redacted in the document, indicating an active investigation with protected identities.
